article.description: Illinois never had a chance against Wisconsin in the Big Ten tournament championship game.
article.headline: Harris leads Badgers with 29 points
article.linkText: Wisconsin shuts down Illinois for Big Ten crown
article.story: INDIANAPOLIS (AP) -- It's been a while since Illinois coach Bruce Weber had to talk to his team after a loss. "For the first time in a long time, things didn't go our way," Weber said after Illinois lost to Wisconsin 70-53 in the Big Ten tournament championship Sunday. The loss snapped a 12-game winning streak that began after Illinois lost at Wisconsin on Jan. 24. But it didn't take long for the good news to start flowing again. Illinois received a No. 5 seed in the NCAA tournament on Sunday, one spot better than Wisconsin, which was seeded sixth despite beating Illinois twice this season. The Badgers (24-6) will face 11th-seeded Richmond in the first round in nearby Milwaukee. Illinois (24-6) will play 12th-seeded Murray State in Columbus, Ohio. Michigan State joined Wisconsin and Illinois as the only three Big Ten teams to get in, which miffed Illinois guard Dee Brown. "We're not getting much respect at all," Brown said. "The three teams that got in have to prove a point. Michigan State proved a point last year (by making the South regional final) and now we're all going to be looking to do the same thing this year." The Illini will have to start from scratch to do it, thanks to Devin Harris. The tournament's most outstanding player scored 29 points on 10-of-16 shooting to lead Wisconsin to its first Big Ten tournament title. "We're going to have to regroup," Illinois forward James Augustine said. "If you can't regroup, you're going to be out in the first round." The 10th-ranked Badgers held Illinois to a season-low 32.7 percent shooting, but Weber still has good reason to be optimistic. "The last time we lost to Wisconsin, we won 12 in a row," he said. "Let's see what happens now." Illinois is headed to its fifth straight NCAA tournament. Last year, the fourth-seeded Illini lost to fifth-seeded Notre Dame 68-60 in the West Regional. "I feel good about it," Brown said of the team's seeding. "We're in the tournament. As long as you're in the tournament, you have to be happy because a lot of people didn't get in." The Badgers, who reached the Final Four in 2000, seem primed for another deep tournament run. They have won seven straight games with a balanced offense and smothering defense. Wisconsin will make its sixth straight NCAA tournament appearance, and seventh in eight years. The Badgers lost to top-seeded Kentucky in last year's Midwest Regional semifinal 63-57. Coach Bo Ryan and the rest of the team chose to focus on the location of their first-round game rather than their surprisingly high No. 6 seed. "It's good for us to be close to home," Ryan said. "We'll get great fan support." Combine that with Harris and Mike Wilkinson, who combined for 124 points in the three games and were both named to the all-tournament team, and it makes Wisconsin a dangerous team. Illinois can attest to that. The Badgers set the tone in the opening seven minutes, shooting over 50 percent from the field and outrebounding Illinois 9-1. Clayton Hanson's hook shot gave Wisconsin a 16-6 lead. Illinois shot 29 percent in the first half. Brown kept Illinois in it with 11 points on 4-of-6 shooting. His teammates managed just 12 points on 3-of-18 shooting. Brown finished with 15 points on 6-of-12 shooting, and his teammates were 10-for-37 from the field. Wilkinson had 11 points and five rebounds for Wisconsin, which can't wait to get back home. "We were hoping for Milwaukee," Harris said. "We got a high seed, but we're playing close to home so it worked itself out."
